awd_titl_txt: Narrative Modeling with StoryQ: Integrating Mathematics, Language Arts, and Computing to Create Pathways to Artificial Intelligence Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
The future workforce is being drastically reshaped by artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. The advancement in AI theories, algorithms and practices has not only created great demands for AI scientists, engineers, technicians and entrepreneurs, but also reformulated the nature of work in almost all industries. Importantly today's students must gain a fundamental understanding of AI in order to be prepared to enter the workforce of the future. This project will design a 12-lesson high school curriculum called StoryQ and associated teaching guides that will provide students with firsthand experience on how narrative modeling, one of the oldest fields in artificial intelligence, can be developed while working on their language arts writing projects. By integrating age-appropriate mathematics, language arts, and computing concepts, researchers will leverage advanced data exploration and text mining technologies, and employ research-based pedagogical approaches to help high school students learn basic concepts in machine learning and artificial intelligence. This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program, which supports projects that build understandings of practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to increasing students' knowledge and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and information and communication technology (ICT) careers. 

Led by a multidisciplinary team of learning technology and data experts, machine learning researchers, and experts in the integration of narrative modeling and mathematics learning, the project will focus on helping students envision their future careers as powered by artificial intelligence. The researchers will create and test StoryQ, a web-based text mining and narrative modeling platform, and develop, implement, and test narrative modeling with StoryQ curriculum. Students will learn to design, build, test, and iteratively improve machine learning models of narratives sourced both from student and teacher selected literature and from students’ own writings. Beginning with core narrative concepts, students will engage in development cycles that lead them to explore their own writing, annotate models by hand, observe a trained text mining model at work, become familiar with error analysis, and ultimately build their own AI model and evaluation process. The project broadens participation among youth from underrepresented and underserved populations by recruiting participants from two Massachusetts school districts with ethnically and economically diverse populations. To create broadly inclusive learning experiences, students from diverse backgrounds will write narratives to express their cultures and personalities as part of the learning activities. Research questions include (1) How can learning environments be designed to help students understand core AI concepts including the structures in unstructured data and the roles of human insight in the development of AI technologies? and (2) How can learning environments be designed to help students develop awareness and interest in careers that are centered on text mining practices or broadly powered by AI technologies? The project will use a design-based research design. The research team will carry out class observations and in-depth analysis of observational data, and draw design principles for building learning environments that cultivate future STEM and ICT workforce. The project’s success will be evaluated by a group of external evaluators who are experts in diversity and inclusion in AI, computing education, mathematics education, and language arts and literacy education. The outcomes of the project include the resulting web-delivered classroom-ready AI curriculum modules, a teaching guide and teacher resources for high schools, which will be disseminated to teachers and professional development groups. The StoryQ technology will be freely distributed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Narrative Modeling with StoryQ project aimed to develop and test learning tools and activities for secondary students to learn about Artificial Intelligence (AI) and increase their interest in AI-related careers. To engage all students—particularly those from demographic groups historically underrepresented in computing, such as female, Black or African American, and Hispanic or Latino students—the project focused on integrating AI topics into core courses like English, Social Studies, Science, and Computer Science (CS, which is available to all students in some schools).

The project team developed StoryQ, a learning tool with which students in grades 6 to 12 can explore text classification models, a common type of AI that processes language. StoryQ is embedded in the web-based CODAP data exploration environment. It has a simple, drag-and-drop graphical interface that makes it fun and accessible for younger learners, especially those with limited math backgrounds. It allows students to see how AI systems process language and compare that to human understanding. Through StoryQ, students can engage with key machine learning tasks, such as preparing data, extracting and evaluating features, training and testing models, identifying and analyzing errors, and iteratively improving models. Its interactive and visually engaging design and conceptual depth have been the main reasons why students have reported positive learning experiences. StoryQ is free and open source, hosted by the Concord Consortium at http://concord.org/storyq/app. 

Leveraging StoryQ’s rich functionalities, the project team created a flagship curriculum module, Exploring AI in English Language Arts with StoryQ (freely available at https://learn.concord.org/storyq). The module integrates AI topics into English classes, focusing on how humans and AI understand language differently. Students explore how AI models store knowledge and “read” text, how AI developers’ choices affect the quality of these models, and how they can use their English skills to improve them. At the same time, students get to practice close reading and creative writing. A pilot test with 7 teachers and 437 students during the 2022-23 academic year showed promising results: students developed an understanding of AI concepts and statistical reasoning skills. They reported feeling more confident working with AI and interested in learning more about AI. They also became more aware of AI job opportunities and thought of many ways to apply AI to real-world problems. 

In the 2023-24 academic year, the project team conducted a feasibility study of a new version adapted for flexible use in both English and CS classes across grades 6 to 12 and a larger-scale remote teacher training and implementation for broad impact. In collaboration with the Center for Cyber Education at Mississippi State University, the project team recruited and trained 16 CS teachers from 11 schools in Mississippi and supported them in implementing the module, reaching 876 students. The study established the feasibility of remote training and support with an 8:1 teacher-trainer ratio. The module was well-received by teachers and students. Without exception, all teachers expressed the desire to fully incorporate the module into their teaching.

In addition to the flagship module, the project team developed curriculum modules for social studies and science classes. Field tests showed that students were highly engaged in AI-powered exploration of primary sources for historical inquiry and were eager to learn more about scientific advancement accelerated by AI.

Alongside the development work, the project conducted multiple studies focused on how students learn AI and core subjects together, how teachers integrate AI topics into their teaching, and how learning analytics can help understand student engagement and learning. Together, these findings contribute to the growing knowledge base of AI education research and practices.

AI researchers on the project also conducted basic research in Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing to inspire new directions in learning experience design. One example is the analysis of language from a social perspective, which influenced the development of the History module. The basic research aimed at the characterization of language patterns that signal social identity and how these respond to social movements communicated in the media. The researchers have worked on ways of incorporating simple language models into the curriculum to scaffold understanding and engage students in taking a critical stance toward media hype

During the funding period, the project reached 40 teachers and over 1500 students across 22 schools in 8 states, making a meaningful impact on their understanding of and interest in AI. The research efforts resulted in a strong record of scholarly publications, including 11 journal articles, 3 dissertations, and 26 conference papers and presentations, advancing the fields of AI education, learning technologies, learning sciences, and AI research. The project laid the groundwork for several new initiatives, including integrating AI education across the school curriculum, enhancing math education through AI-related contexts, and creating learning tools for students to explore neural networks.
